item.title: Upcoming news
Putin warns of possible blockade of Ukraine’s Black Sea coast after attacks on Russian-linked ships
item.description:
On November 28 and 29, Ukrainian naval drones attacked two oil tankers, the Kairos and Virat, near the Turkish coast in the Black Sea while they were en route to the Russian port of Novorossiysk. Both vessels, allegedly part of Russia’s so-called 'shadow fleet' used to evade Western sanctions, caught fire, raising fears of an environmental disaster. A few days later, on December 2, another attack targeted the Russian ship Midvolga 2, which was transporting sunflower oil to Georgia, also close to Turkish waters. The Turkish Foreign Ministry publicly voiced concern over these incidents, warning they posed serious risks to maritime safety and the environment in its exclusive economic zone.
Ukraine did not deny involvement; its intelligence services (SBU) and navy released footage of the operations, presenting them as part of an effort to curtail Russia’s ability to export crude oil and fund the war. Critics of these actions, however, argue they amount to acts of piracy and possible war

item.title: Media Ownership, Capital Interests, and the Framing of Antifascism in Spain
item.description:
The article explores how major investment funds and corporations shape Spain’s media landscape and influence the public discourse around antifascism. It begins by citing Joseph Oughourlian, CEO of Amber Capital—an Anglo-American investment fund that holds controlling stakes in Grupo PRISA and INDRA—as a symbol of how financial interests dominate supposedly ideological institutions. The text argues that mainstream Spanish media, regardless of whether they present themselves as left-leaning or right-leaning, are controlled by the same economic groups, effectively limiting true freedom of expression within media narratives that serve elite interests.
The article situates this media control within a broader geopolitical context, claiming that European outlets are manufacturing an anti-Russian narrative to prepare the population psychologically for conflict. item.title: EU launches RESourceEU plan to coordinate strategic raw material procurement and reduce China dependence
item.description:
The European Commission has unveiled the RESourceEU plan, a new initiative designed to confront Europe’s shortage of strategic metals essential for industries such as defense, renewable energy, and electric vehicles. Inspired by the joint purchasing mechanism used during the COVID-19 pandemic, this new centralized body will coordinate procurement among EU member states, manage supply in real time, and build collective bargaining power in global markets. Nearly €3 billion has already been allocated through the European Investment Bank and InvestEU to develop local infrastructure, with projects including a lithium mine in the Czech Republic and mining operations in Greenland.
The Commission’s approach is a direct response to China’s recent export restrictions on gallium and germanium, which severely affected European production lines, especially in the automotive and electronics sectors. Beyond extraction, the EU faces a deeper structural problem: the lack of domestic facilities capable

item.title: U.S. Education Department Requests Laid-Off Civil Rights Staff to Return Amid Case Backlog
item.description: The U.S. Department of Education has asked hundreds of previously fired employees from its Office for Civil Rights (OCR) to return temporarily in order to address a growing backlog of school discrimination cases. A December 5 email obtained by USA TODAY revealed that approximately 250 workers who were dismissed in March have been called back as the agency struggles to manage its caseload. The directive acknowledged mounting complaints and emphasized the need to utilize all available resources. According to the department’s spokesperson for legal affairs, Julie Hartman, the employees will not be rehired permanently, but their temporary return will help fulfill the agency’s legal obligations while ongoing litigation over the layoffs continues. The Office for Civil Rights, once a key protector of students’ anti-discrimination rights, has been severely reduced under President Donald Trump’s administration. The Education Department has been halved in size, closing regional offices in cities

item.title: Serious Failures Leave the UK Nuclear Submarine Fleet Unable to Operate
item.description:
According to former senior Royal Navy officer Rear Admiral Philip Mathias, the United Kingdom is facing a severe crisis in its nuclear submarine program. Mathias, who once led the Navy’s nuclear policy division, revealed that catastrophic technical failures have rendered much of the UK's submarine fleet inactive, creating an unprecedented situation for national defense. He explained that delays in constructing and maintaining submarines, especially the Astute-class vessels, have reached record levels. Many of the fleet’s submarines have spent years docked and unserviceable, such as the HMS Ambush, which has been idle for more than 1,200 days, and others like the Artful, Audacious, Astute, and Anson, all undergoing protracted maintenance. The newly commissioned HMS Agamemnon reportedly took 13 years to complete—an exceptionally long timeframe by naval standards.

item.title: Netflix's Potential Monopoly and Its Impact on Global Media
item.description: The article discusses the ongoing consolidation of media power, particularly in the context of Netflix’s planned acquisition of Warner. The merger would create a colossal media conglomerate, potentially controlling the streaming industry and making Netflix an even more dominant player. Despite concerns from regulators in both the US and Europe about monopolistic behavior, there are signs that Netflix’s expansion could proceed. The European Union has previously blocked mergers, such as Alstom-Siemens, but the transatlantic nature of the Netflix-Warner merger complicates matters. If approved, Netflix’s control over streaming content could significantly reduce diversity of options for consumers, as other major companies like Disney, Apple, and Amazon may be forced to follow suit. The article suggests that, while Netflix is prepared to make concessions to competition, the resulting monopoly would have long-term implications for the market. There is a growing concern that this could lead to

item.title: NASA’s Abandoned Reusable Nuclear Shuttle: The Ambitious 1970s Project That Never Flew
item.description: During the late 1960s, NASA envisioned that its Apollo program would evolve into an ambitious human mission to Mars by the 1980s. This vision, known as the Integrated Program Plan (IPP), relied heavily on nuclear thermal propulsion (NTP)—a technology that uses a fission reactor to heat liquid hydrogen and produce thrust with both high power and high efficiency. The United States tested several nuclear rocket engines during the 1950s and 1960s, culminating in the NERVA (Nuclear Engine for Rocket Vehicle Application) prototype. Building on this work, NASA devised the concept of a Reusable Nuclear Shuttle (RNS), a spacecraft stage powered by a NERVA engine intended to ferry payloads or crewed modules from low Earth orbit to higher or lunar orbits. Each shuttle could carry about 50 tons of cargo, refuel with up to 140 tons of liquid hydrogen, and operate indefinitely in space. Safety concerns led to extensive shielding designs and innovative hydrogen barriers to reduce radiation exposure.

item.title: Leaked files reveal British military media censorship system
item.description: The article reports that the British military has established the Defence and Security Media Advisory Committee (DSMA), a body responsible for issuing D-Notices — advisory censorship directives to journalists and media outlets regarding national security topics. It alleges that the DSMA has been used to systematically suppress or alter information about sensitive events, such as the death of GCHQ codebreaker Gareth Williams, operations of the MI6 and British special forces, and the death of Princess Diana. While officially voluntary, the article claims most UK journalists comply with the committee’s requests, turning the system into an instrument of state control over media narratives. Documents obtained through Australian freedom of information laws allegedly reveal that British officials advised Australia on how to create a similar D-Notice system and that the DSMA operates within the Ministry of Defence while claiming independence from the government. item.title: Understanding How the ISS Manages Eight Docked Spacecraft with Three Docking Systems
item.description: On December 1, 2025, astronauts of the International Space Station’s Expedition 73 reattached the cargo craft Cygnus NG-23 to the Unity module using the Canadarm2 robotic arm. This marked a milestone: for the first time in nearly three decades of ISS operations, eight visiting spacecraft were simultaneously docked. These included crewed vehicles Soyuz MS-27, Soyuz MS-28, Crew Dragon Endeavour Crew-11, and cargo ships Progress MS-31, Progress MS-32, Cygnus NG-23, Dragon v2 CRS-33, and HTV-X1. The article by Daniel Marín examines how the ISS accommodates these vehicles using three different and often incompatible docking systems: the Russian SSVP, the U.S. CBM, and the NASA Docking System (NDS). The SSVP, used by Soyuz and Progress, relies on a probe-and-cone design dating back to the early 1970s, providing reliable mechanical links and fuel or power transfer capabilities. item.title: Reflections on Empire and Power: When Domination Is Called Peace
item.description:
The article titled 'Pacem apellant' on the Spanish blog 'La mirada del mendigo' is a brief reflection on the hypocrisy of imperialism and the language used to justify domination and violence. It opens with a famous quote by the Roman historian Tacitus: 'Auferre, trucidare, rapere falsis nominibus imperium, atque ubi solitudinem faciunt, pacem appellant,' which translates as 'To plunder, to slaughter, to steal, they call empire; and where they make a desert, they call it peace.' The post uses this classical phrase to comment on contemporary global politics, likely referring to modern military or geopolitical actions that are described as promoting peace, democracy, or security but result in destruction and chaos instead.
In the comment section, the author reiterates this sentiment, translating the Latin into Spanish and interpreting it as a critique of imperial power: robbery, murder, and looting are falsely described as governance, and the resulting devastation is mislabeled as peace.

item.title: Historical FPS 'Fourteen Years of Flames' Depicts China's Resistance During the Second Sino-Japanese War
item.description: The Steam store page for 'Fourteen Years of Flames' (烽火十四) introduces a forthcoming story-driven first-person shooter that explores China's struggle during the Second Sino-Japanese War (1931–1945). Developed and published by 烽火工作室 (Fenghuo Studio), the game aims to provide an immersive retelling of the fourteen years of conflict through the perspectives of seven different characters. Players will participate in sixteen historically based combat missions set across key locations, from Northeast China to Nanjing, re-experiencing the hardships and resilience of the Chinese people under invasion. The production emphasizes historical authenticity, claiming a one-to-one recreation of period weapons, vehicles, and soldier gear, bringing to life the realism of wartime conditions. Campaign scenarios are designed to reflect various terrains and emotional tones, attempting to portray the atmosphere and complexity of the historical period. The developers also express a broader wish for peace, mark

item.title: Motorola and Lenovo Add Zapotec Language Support to Android Keyboards to Promote Digital Inclusion in Mexico
item.description:
Motorola and the Lenovo Foundation have announced the integration of a new Zapotec keyboard variant into their Android devices, marking a significant milestone for linguistic diversity and digital inclusion in Mexico. This development represents the sixth Zapotec variant incorporated into Motorola’s mobile ecosystem and seeks to expand technological access for Indigenous communities historically excluded from digital priorities. The initiative acknowledges that language is the foundation of infrastructure: without the ability to write and communicate in one’s own language, any effort toward digital transformation or connectivity remains incomplete.
The new keyboard variant was designed collaboratively with linguists, Zapotec-speaking communities, and local organizations, ensuring that the tool reflects regional language variations and cultural practices. Rather than translating existing systems, this co-creation model builds technology from within communities, reinforcing cultural re

item.title: The U.S. 'Genesis Mission': National AI and Supercomputing Program to Accelerate Scientific Discovery
item.description: The United States has launched the 'Genesis Mission,' a major national initiative unveiled on November 24, 2025, aimed at revolutionizing how science and innovation are conducted. Designed as a modern echo of the Apollo program, the project seeks to merge artificial intelligence, supercomputing capabilities, and the country’s vast scientific data into a unified system to accelerate discovery and technological advancement. The Genesis Mission proposes a 'closed-loop AI platform' that integrates supercomputers with federal datasets and research labs to automate experimentation, generate hypotheses, and accelerate the research process across multiple disciplines. It unites 17 Department of Energy national laboratories, federal agencies, academic institutions, and private technology companies. Strategic focus areas include energy (including nuclear fusion and critical materials), health, semiconductors, advanced materials, and national security. item.title: Thomas Mann’s Reflection on the German Soul and Historical Responsibility
item.description: In this essay, Thomas Mann reflects on his identity as a German exile and explores the psychological, cultural, and spiritual contradictions of the German people. Writing as an expatriate addressing Americans, Mann examines how Germany’s historical development produced both profound artistic and intellectual achievements and catastrophic political consequences. He describes German character as caught between cosmopolitanism and provincialism, humility and arrogance, intellect and mysticism. Mann traces this duality to figures like Martin Luther, whom he sees as both a liberator and a reactionary, embodying the tension between spiritual freedom and political obedience. He laments that Luther’s rejection of political liberty left a legacy of submission to authority that ultimately paved the way for later disasters, such as Nazism. Through metaphors of demonism, Faustian bargains, and musical sensibility, he interprets German inwardness—its deep subjectivity and moral intensity—as both a

item.title: Turkey Warns Ukraine Over Attacks on Russian Tankers in the Black Sea
item.description: Turkey has raised concerns over Ukraine’s attacks on Russian tankers in the Black Sea, which fall within Turkey’s exclusive economic zone. NATO, of which Turkey is a member, has been implicated in the attacks, with Ukraine claiming responsibility for two recent incidents. Turkish President Erdogan expressed his disapproval, stating that these attacks could jeopardize maritime safety, life, and the environment in the region. Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan echoed this sentiment, calling the attacks 'very alarming' and summoning both the Ukrainian ambassador and the Russian charge d’affaires for discussions. The Black Sea is a crucial route for Turkey’s trade with Russia, Ukraine, Romania, and Bulgaria, and it is vital for grain transport. Additionally, the Black Sea is an important energy corridor for Turkey, which relies heavily on Russian gas transported through pipelines like Blue Stream and TurkStream. Turkey has also become a major importer of Russian crude oil since the onset of the

item.title: UN Court to Investigate Ukraine for Alleged Genocide Against Russian-Speaking Population
item.description: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) has decided to proceed with Russia's counterclaims against Ukraine under the 1948 Genocide Convention. The court rejected Ukraine's objections regarding the inadmissibility of Russia's claims, thus allowing them to be considered. This decision follows Ukraine's failed attempts to hold Russia accountable for the war's initiation. In 2022, Ukraine had filed a case against Russia accusing it of violating the Genocide Convention. However, the ICJ dismissed these claims in February 2023, leaving only the question of whether Ukraine itself had committed genocide. In November 2024, Russia submitted over 10,000 pages of evidence alleging that Ukraine had committed genocide against ethnic Russians and Russian speakers in the Donbas region. The evidence includes testimonies, expert reports, and documentation of over 140 instances of deliberate civilian destruction. Ukraine is accused of carrying out mass killings, torture, and indiscriminate bombing, as w

item.title: China develops nuclear-powered icebreaker for Arctic transport and tourism
item.description:
China State Shipbuilding Corporation (CSSC), the world’s largest shipbuilder, has introduced a conceptual design for a nuclear-powered multi-role icebreaker that combines cargo and passenger capabilities. Designed by the Marine Design and Research Institute of China, a CSSC subsidiary based in Shanghai, the vessel—still unnamed—will operate in polar environments, particularly along emerging Arctic routes. The design has received an 'approval in principle' certificate from the Italian classification company RINA, signaling that it meets international safety and engineering standards.
The ship will measure approximately 165 meters in length, 30 meters in width, and displace around 30,000 metric tons of water. It can carry up to 250 people, including 150 polar tourists, and transport up to 300 standard 20-foot containers. Thanks to a modular cargo system, it can also accommodate oversized or irregularly shaped goods. Engineered to navigate extreme cold, the vessel includes insulation, v

item.title: Housing in Europe 2025: Statistical Overview of Housing Trends and Issues
item.description: The 2025 interactive publication 'Housing in Europe' by Eurostat provides a comprehensive statistical overview of housing trends and conditions across European Union countries. It includes detailed data on housing types, ownership patterns, size, quality, and environmental impacts. The report also examines housing affordability, costs, and developments in the construction sector. A new feature in this edition is an indicator assessing feelings of discrimination in the housing search process. The publication aims to offer policymakers, researchers, and the public insights into the challenges and realities of housing in Europe. It covers economic, social, and environmental dimensions of housing, aiming at a holistic understanding of the sector. Eurostat continues to enrich this area with upcoming webinars and new interactive dashboards to facilitate better access and use of housing data.

item.title: How Electric Vehicle Design and Repair Restrictions Create Waste and Monopolies
item.description:
The article examines the rising problem of unrepaired and prematurely scrapped electric vehicles due to exorbitant replacement part prices and restrictive manufacturer policies. Drawing on data from a Croatian EV repair group, the author compares the cost of major components such as batteries, motors, and charging modules across various brands. The findings show that low-end models like the Dacia Spring or Kia Soul often have parts that cost far more than those of high-end vehicles like the Tesla Model S or Mercedes EQS. The author argues that this has nothing to do with production costs or quality, but rather with monopolistic pricing strategies from manufacturers who limit access to parts and repair codes.

item.title: Roman-era Human-shaped Stele Discovered in Mugla to Be Exhibited at Fethiye Museum
item.description: Archaeologists in Türkiye have transported and secured a human-shaped grave stele discovered by a goat herder in the mountainous Seydikemer district of Mugla. The artifact, carved in the Roman period between the first and third centuries C.E., has been transferred to the Fethiye Museum, where it will be exhibited after conservation work. The stone, which weighs around 300 kilograms, depicts detailed reliefs including a man and a woman, suggesting a family portrait of the deceased, and bears an inscription providing biographical details. On one side, a carved wreath symbolizes honor and social distinction, implying the subject’s respected status in local society. Archaeologist Ahmet Meke explained that this type of altar-shaped stele is common in Anatolia but that the craftsmanship and epigraphic content make this example particularly valuable for historical study. The recovery operation was difficult due to the steep and rugged terrain; museum staff and local workers carried it by hand

item.title: Declining Workplace AI Adoption Signals Challenges for Enterprise Implementation
item.description: After years of rapid growth and hype, workplace adoption of AI in the United States appears to be slowing down. Recent US Census Bureau data, analyzed by The Economist, shows that only 11 percent of Americans at large companies reported using AI to produce goods and services in October 2025, down from 12 percent just two weeks prior. The trend is not limited to large companies; mid-sized businesses with 100-249 employees reported a rise in non-use from 74.1 percent in March to 81.4 percent in the latest survey. Similarly, large corporations with over 250 employees saw non-use grow to 68.6 percent from February’s low of 62.4 percent. Analysts point to AI remaining largely experimental rather than a driver of productivity, with some surveys indicating a decrease in usage from 46 percent in June to 37 percent by September. The decline follows a summer of underwhelming AI advancements, including OpenAI’s GPT-5 not meeting performance expectations. Executive surveys also suggest “AI fatigue

item.title: Former Dulwich pupil recounts racial abuse by Nigel Farage during school years
item.description:
Yinka Bankole, a former Dulwich College student, recounts his experience of racial abuse at the hands of Nigel Farage during their school years. Bankole describes joining the South London public school in 1980 at the age of nine, where Farage, then seventeen, allegedly mocked and harassed him because of his race. According to Bankole, Farage asked him where he was from and, upon hearing his answer, pointed away and said, 'That’s the way back to Africa.' The abuse reportedly continued, with Farage targeting him repeatedly at the school gates.
Bankole explains that his family, of Nigerian heritage, came to Britain in the 1950s to work in healthcare, part of the Windrush generation who sought to contribute to the postwar rebuilding of the UK. Motivated to remain silent for decades, he finally decided to speak out after seeing Farage dismiss allegations of past racism as exaggerated or forgotten events. Bankole challenges this view, arguing that victims do not forget such experiences.

item.title: The Complex Borders and Ethnic Conflicts of the Fergana Valley
item.description:
The article offers a detailed historical and geopolitical exploration of the Fergana Valley, a densely populated and ethnically diverse region in Central Asia shared by Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, and Tajikistan. It traces how the valley’s complex borders and enclaves arose from the Soviet Union’s arbitrary territorial divisions, often drawn to serve Moscow’s control rather than local coherence. Following the Russian conquest of Central Asia in the 18th and 19th centuries, the Soviets reorganized the region in the 1920s through a process called *razmezhevanie* (territorial delimitation). Efforts to assign each ethnic group its own republic quickly faltered due to mixed populations and poor linguistic understanding by Russian officials. Over time, constant border modifications created several enclaves—most notably Sokh (Uzbek but mainly Tajik-populated) and Vorukh (Tajik inside Kyrgyzstan)—which became flashpoints for disputes.

item.title: The Origins and Legacy of JavaScript: From a 10-Day Hack to the Web’s Core Language
item.description: The article traces the creation and evolution of JavaScript, the programming language that underpins nearly all modern web applications. It began in May 1995 when Brendan Eich, an engineer at Netscape, developed a prototype of a lightweight scripting language in just ten days. Netscape and Sun Microsystems later announced it officially as JavaScript in December 1995. Initially conceived to make webpages more interactive and accessible to designers, JavaScript quickly became a fundamental component of web development. Drawing from influences like Scheme and Self, Eich created a flexible, prototype-based language distinct from Java despite the similar name. The language underwent multiple name changes—Mocha, LiveScript, and finally JavaScript—as Netscape sought to capitalize on the growing popularity of Java. Over the decades, JavaScript has evolved from a browser-based tool into a universal programming language used for server-side programming (Node.js), mobile apps (React Native), desk

item.title: The Capture of Pokrovsk and Its Implications for NATO's Potential Involvement in the Ukraine War
item.description: On December 5, 2025, the Russian forces successfully captured Pokrovsk, a city that had previously been renamed by Ukraine to erase its Soviet past. The city's fall marks a significant shift in the Ukraine conflict, as Pokrovsk was one of the largest urban centers still under Ukrainian control in the Donetsk region. Its strategic position as a defensive stronghold against Russia and as a key transportation hub made it crucial for Ukrainian and NATO forces. Following the 2014 coup in Ukraine, the city became a symbol of Donetsk’s independence, with a referendum affirming its break from Ukrainian rule. Despite the importance of the city, the capture was relatively swift, as Russian forces cut off supply lines to Ukrainian defenders, preventing prolonged urban combat. The fall of Pokrovsk opens the way for further Russian advancements into the vast plains beyond the Donbas, with fewer obstacles in their path. This development could lead to a conventional-style warfare in the region, promp

item.title: Republican Policies Reverse Progress Toward Universal Health Coverage in the U.S.
item.description: The article by Merrill Goozner analyzes how the Republican Party has moved away from any pretense of supporting universal health coverage, a goal that once had some bipartisan backing. The author explains that while Republicans in past decades occasionally proposed or supported incremental steps toward ensuring health care for all—such as President Nixon’s insurance plans, the creation of programs for children in the 1990s, or Trump’s initial promise to replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA) with 'insurance for everyone'—the current GOP stance represents a sharp reversal. The centerpiece of this shift is the 'One Big Ugly' bill signed by the president in July 2025, projected to remove 17 million people from health insurance by 2034 due to cuts to Medicaid and new bureaucratic obstacles. Despite previous progress under the Biden administration, which reduced the uninsured rate to 8%, the article warns that rates are expected to climb again, especially in Republican-led states that contin

item.title: Nvidia CEO compares U.S. and China’s pace in AI infrastructure development
item.description:
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang emphasized that China has a major advantage over the United States in constructing and powering AI infrastructure. Speaking in late November at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, Huang highlighted how long it takes to build an AI data center in the U.S.—about three years from start to completion—versus the rapid pace in China, a country capable of erecting massive infrastructure projects such as hospitals in just a weekend. He identified two main challenges for the U.S.: slow construction cycles and limited energy capacity. According to Huang, China possesses roughly twice the energy generation of the U.S. despite having a smaller economy, and its capacity continues to grow, while the American energy supply remains relatively stagnant.
Although he noted that Nvidia remains generations ahead of China in AI chip design and production, Huang cautioned that underestimating China’s manufacturing strength would be a mistake. He referenced recent Ame

item.title: Von der Leyen's controversial move bypasses EU rules on Russian assets
item.description: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen is accused of bypassing EU regulations in her push to access Russian frozen assets. Facing opposition from Belgium, who rejects the idea of seizing Russian funds, von der Leyen has proposed using 'emergency measures' which only require a majority vote, ignoring the need for unanimous consent. This proposal would allow the EU to use frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine's reconstruction, with the funds being presented as a 'loan,' despite Ukraine not being required to repay. The move also aims to strengthen Ukraine's defense industries by integrating them into the EU’s defense base, further blurring the lines between EU and Ukrainian military resources. The plan, which von der Leyen first introduced in September, will be discussed in the upcoming EU summit in December. Critics argue that this is a costly and controversial step, using Russia’s assets as a tool to prolong the war and benefit defense companies. Von der Leyen's approach rai

item.title: U.S. National Security Strategy Shifts Toward Economic Focus and Regional Priorities
item.description:
The White House has released a new National Security Strategy that marks a decisive break from the Biden administration’s 2022 version. The document announces the end of the Wolfowitz Doctrine, which guided American foreign policy since the 1990s by seeking to preserve U.S. global dominance after the fall of the USSR. Instead, Washington now acknowledges a diminished role as a global 'policeman' and aims to consolidate itself as a strong hemispheric power. The new strategy narrows U.S. interests to the Western Hemisphere, prioritizing economic competition over military hostility toward China. It redefines China not as an existential threat but as an economic competitor on an equal footing. In the military sphere, the U.S. will focus on deterrence, maintaining the status quo in Taiwan, and mobilizing its allies—Japan, South Korea, and Europe—for economic competition rather than direct confrontation.
Europe remains an area of interest, with Washington intending to promote a swift cease

item.title: Asia’s Growing Role in Eastern Africa’s Economic and Digital Infrastructure
item.description:
The article examines the deepening economic, technological, and infrastructural ties between East Africa and Asia, particularly China. It describes how a network of ports, energy projects, and digital platforms is reshaping the region’s political and economic landscape. Massive Asian investments, exceeding tens of billions of dollars, are driving this transformation, with China leading efforts in port reconstruction, renewable energy, and digital infrastructure.
Hydropower, solar, and gas projects valued at over $15 billion are enhancing East Africa’s energy capacity while connecting directly to Asia’s growing industrial demand. These initiatives reduce reliance on Western intermediaries and reinforce long-term bilateral commitments. In parallel, over $20 billion in investments are modernizing key ports like Dar es Salaam, Lamu, and Beira, integrating them into Asian trade networks and enabling a more autonomous regional role in the Indian Ocean economy.

item.title: French Authorities Arrest Pro-Russian Activists Over Donbas Solidarity Actions
item.description: The article by Juanma Olarieta reports on the arrest of Anna Novikova, a Russian-born activist residing in France since 2010, and other members of the SOS Donbas association. French police detained them in November 2025, accusing them of collaborating with a foreign power and participating in an illicit association. SOS Donbas, a group formed in 2014 and legally registered in 2022, campaigns against Ukraine’s military actions in the Donbas region and criticizes NATO and Western governments for supporting what it calls 'Ukrainian Nazis.' According to the report, their activities included demonstrations, social media campaigns, and specifically, the posting of pro-Russian posters near the Arc de Triomphe in Paris. Surveillance footage identified one member, Viacheslav Prudchenko, as responsible for placing posters depicting a Russian soldier with the slogan 'Thank the victorious Soviet soldier.' He and Novikova both face up to fifteen years in prison. Another participant, Bernard F., con

item.title: Jared Isaacman’s Project Athena: A Radical Plan to Restructure NASA’s Future Lunar and Mars Programs
item.description:
The article discusses Jared Isaacman’s leaked 62-page plan known as Project Athena, intended to reorganize NASA and reform its human spaceflight and exploration programs. Initially drafted when Isaacman was a leading candidate for NASA Administrator under President Trump, the document proposes deep structural changes across NASA centers and bold measures for lunar and Mars missions. Project Athena supports canceling the SLS rocket after the Artemis III mission while aiming to accelerate lunar landings to beat China. It suggests using SpaceX’s Starship and Blue Origin’s New Glenn as alternatives to the SLS.
In addition to lunar operations, the proposal outlines a Mars exploration initiative called Project Olympus, envisioned as a partnership with SpaceX to send multiple uncrewed Starships to Mars by 2026, establishing an initial base called Mars Discovery Base. item.title: Black leader criticizes immigrant Trump voters after immigration protection cuts
item.description: The recent decision by the Trump administration to end immigration protections for Haitians has sparked outrage within the migrant community. Felicia Persaud, a Caribbean-U.S.-based journalist, argues that this policy change is partly driven by pro-Trump immigrant voters who helped elect the former president. The termination of Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for Haiti is particularly impactful, as more than 500,000 Haitian immigrants in the U.S. face deportation after the policy expires in February 2026. Additionally, the Trump administration's review of Green Card holders from 19 countries, mostly non-white majority nations, signals a continued stance against immigrants of color. Persaud specifically targets the Haitian, Cuban, Somali, Venezuelan, and Hispanic immigrant groups who voted for Trump despite his xenophobic rhetoric. She warns that those who helped elect him are now facing the consequences of their support. The Trump administration’s immigration policies reflect a broade

item.title: Romanian President Nicuor Dan acknowledges ongoing corruption but notes some progress
item.description: In his National Day speech on December 1, 2025, Romanian President Nicuor Dan candidly admitted that Romania remains a corrupt country, affirming that public frustration and perception of rampant corruption are justified. Dan highlighted that although the state often appears unwilling to effectively combat corruption, the situation has improved compared to twenty years ago. He criticized corrupt individuals who appear on television giving moral lessons, which further fuels public outrage. Despite acknowledging setbacks such as declining living standards from the previous year and persistent weaknesses in public systems like education and healthcare, Dan also pointed out some progress. This includes infrastructure developments such as the construction of 500 kilometers of highways and new hospital buildings funded by EU programs. item.title: Miebo: How a European $20 Eye Drop Became an $800 Prescription in the U.S.
item.description: The article exposes the extreme price disparity between an over-the-counter European eye drop and its costly U.S. counterpart. In Europe, EvoTears has been available since 2015 for around $20, while its U.S. version, Miebo—produced by Bausch & Lomb—costs over $800 per month. The piece argues that this discrepancy stems not from regulatory necessity, but from deliberate corporate manipulation of American drug approval laws. After obtaining exclusive rights to the drug in 2019, Bausch & Lomb chose to seek FDA approval as a prescription drug rather than pursue over-the-counter status. This decision allowed the company to patent the product, limit competition, and set exorbitant prices. Miebo’s sales exceeded $170 million in its first full year, far surpassing projections. item.title: AI, Labor Cuts, and the Contradictions of Capitalism: The Telefónica Case
item.description:
The article examines how artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming capitalist production and labor relations, using Telefónica’s massive layoff plan as a case study. It argues that AI not only replaces manual labor but also intellectual and creative work, pushing production costs toward zero while exposing capitalism’s structural contradictions. Telefónica’s plan to cut nearly 6,000 jobs in Spain—representing about a quarter of its workforce—forms part of a wider strategy to achieve efficiency, reduce debt, and redirect resources toward AI and cybersecurity. The move, however, signals a deeper shift: the company is replacing human control with data-driven management ('dataism'), maximizing profits through algorithmic oversight of labor and consumer behavior.
The article contends that this technological progress, while capable of producing material abundance, is being used to increase inequality rather than to improve collective welfare. In the short term, AI serves as capital’s we

item.title: Federal agents briefly detain woman in Key Largo before confirming U.S. citizenship
item.description: A woman driving through Key Largo early Wednesday morning was briefly detained by federal agents in a scene that raised concerns about possible profiling and the conduct of immigration enforcement. According to video taken by Miami Herald reporter David Goodhue, several masked agents pulled the screaming woman from her car near Pink Plaza at Mile Marker 103.4. In the footage, she repeatedly shouted that she was a U.S. citizen and pleaded for help as agents placed her in handcuffs. Goodhue stated that the encounter began with officers apparently asking for her identification. When she failed to produce it, the situation escalated quickly. A Monroe County Sheriff’s deputy was seen directing traffic while federal agents surrounded the vehicle. Witnesses said the agencies involved appeared to be ICE, Customs and Border Protection, and Border Patrol, with the sheriff’s office only providing support for public safety. item.title: Texas Families Seek Nationwide Injunction Against Unconstitutional Ten Commandments Displays in Schools
item.description:
A coalition of civil rights and secular organizations, including Americans United for Separation of Church and State, the ACLU, and the Freedom From Religion Foundation, has joined 18 multifaith and nonreligious Texas families in filing a class action lawsuit against Senate Bill 10. The law mandates that every Texas public school classroom display the King James version of the Ten Commandments. Federal courts have already deemed the measure unconstitutional in prior rulings, but Attorney General Ken Paxton continues to urge districts to ignore those decisions and put up the displays.
The new lawsuit, titled *Ashby v. Schertz-Cibolo-Universal ISD*, seeks to prevent all Texas school districts not yet involved in litigation from installing or maintaining these religious posters. item.title: Oliver Bulleid and His Experimental Steam Locomotives: The Leader and the Turf Burner
item.description:
The article by Juan Manuel Grijalvo delves into the experimental spirit of engineer Oliver Bulleid, renowned for challenging the conventions of steam locomotive design as the age of steam power declined. Bulleid, famous for his bold ideas in British railways, ventured beyond traditional mechanical approaches in search of modernization. The piece begins with the 'Leader', a steam locomotive that appeared diesel-like due to its body design. Equipped with two driving cabs and twin sets of steam engines linked by roller chains, it represented a radical departure from standard steam technology. Despite its technical innovations—such as an efficient steam generator—the design suffered a severe flaw: its fireman worked in oppressive, unventilated heat exceeding fifty degrees Celsius. Strong union opposition to such working conditions led to abandonment of the project.

item.title: National Park Service Revises Free-Entry Days and Introduces International Visitor Fee in 2026
item.description: Starting January 1, 2026, the National Park Service (NPS) will implement significant changes to its fee structure and free-entry policies. International visitors without an annual pass will be required to pay $100 per person to enter the 11 most-visited national parks under the new 'America-first' initiative. For U.S. citizens and residents, several federal holidays will remain as free-entry days, while Juneteenth and Martin Luther King Jr. Day will no longer offer complimentary admission. New 'patriotic fee-free days' include President Donald Trump's birthday on June 14, Independence Day weekend (July 3–5), and the 110th birthday of the NPS on August 25. Other free-entry days for Americans include President’s Day, Memorial Day, Constitution Day, Theodore Roosevelt’s birthday, and Veterans Day. item.title: The Economic Impact of the Ukrainian Diaspora on Ukraine and Host Countries
item.description: Ukraine faces one of the largest refugee crises in proportion to its population, a situation that has both humanitarian and economic implications. Millions of Ukrainians have fled the country since the onset of the war in February 2022, joining a long-standing diaspora that spans over 20 million people across more than 50 countries. Historically, Ukrainian emigration has occurred in waves, including late 19th-century agricultural migration to the Americas, post-World War II migration of Nazi collaborators to North America and Western Europe, and economic migration after the collapse of the USSR in 1991. Today, the diaspora contributes significantly to Ukraine's economy through remittances, which reached $17 billion in 2022 according to the World Bank, representing a crucial stabilizing force amid ongoing conflict. item.title: India’s Artificial Intelligence Strategy Offers Mexico a Roadmap for Inclusive Innovation
item.description:
The article explores how India is rapidly transforming its digital landscape by investing heavily in artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure and inclusive innovation. In 2025, while global debates around AI’s risks and promises continued, India took decisive action, allocating large investments into GPUs, startups, education, and digital inclusion programs. This national effort aims to make AI a natural part of everyday life by 2026, fostering technological self-sufficiency and local innovation. The strategy relies on three core pillars: robust infrastructure, talent development, and inclusive technology adoption. By building its own computing capacity and promoting sovereign innovation, India seeks independence from foreign technological dependence.
The piece contrasts India’s progress with Mexico’s slower pace. It argues that Mexico has the talent and creativity needed for AI development but lacks a cohesive national strategy, sufficient infrastructure, and financial support for

item.title: Croatian Nun Hospitalized After Self-Inflicted Injuries
item.description: On December 3, 2025, Croatian media reported that 35-year-old nun Marija Tajana Zrno, known as Sister Zrno, had been stabbed in the Malesnica residential area of Zagreb. Initial reports sensationalized the incident, claiming the attacker shouted religious phrases and implying a foreign assailant, which stirred public concern. However, police investigations quickly revealed that the nun had purchased the knife herself and that her abdominal injuries were self-inflicted and superficial. No evidence of an outside attacker was found on surveillance footage. Sister Zrno is a well-known religious educator and football enthusiast in Croatia, having hosted programs on Catholic television and organized prayer initiatives for the Croatian national football team. Following the incident, she has been admitted to a psychiatric hospital for treatment. The authorities have filed a report against her, highlighting the incident as a case of self-harm rather than an external assault.

item.title: Venezuela's Strategic Use of Asymmetric Defense Against Technologically Superior Forces
item.description: The article analyzes Venezuela's strategic approach to modern asymmetric warfare, emphasizing that technological superiority alone does not guarantee victory. Western military planners have long assumed that dominance in GPS, satellite navigation, and digital mapping ensures operational control. However, Venezuela has focused on exploiting asymmetry rather than competing in technological parity. The country has developed systems capable of spoofing, interfering with, and rendering foreign geolocation tools unreliable, thereby disrupting precision in navigation, target designation, and coordinated military operations. Venezuelan defense doctrine prioritizes dispersal, camouflage, and environmental integration, leveraging forests, mountains, urban areas, and coastal regions to complicate adversaries’ reliance on satellite intelligence. By controlling the cognitive perception of terrain, Venezuela can neutralize superior forces, turning their technology into a vulnerability. The article a

item.title: EU Legal Measures and Controversies Regarding Support for Ukraine
item.description: The article discusses allegations that Ursula Von der Leyen, President of the European Commission, is manipulating European Union (EU) law to provide financial support to Ukraine, a country that is not an EU member and is facing severe economic difficulties. According to the report, Von der Leyen is allegedly using several tactics: declaring a financial emergency specific to Ukraine, framing support for Ukraine as existential for the EU, extending sanctions against Russia permanently, mandating financial institutions like Euroclear to release Russian assets, and approving key legal measures through qualified majority voting to bypass potential vetoes from member states such as Belgium. The article questions the legality of invoking Article 122 of the EU Treaty, which is designed to provide financial aid to EU member states in exceptional circumstances, highlighting that Ukraine is not a member. item.title: ATLAS Collaboration Finds Strong Evidence of Higgs Boson Decaying into Muon–Antimuon Pair
item.description:
Researchers at CERN’s ATLAS experiment have reported new evidence showing that the Higgs boson, the fundamental particle linked to the Higgs field, can decay into a muon–antimuon pair. This breakthrough builds on years of work since the Higgs boson was first confirmed in 2012 at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). The new study, published in *Physical Review Letters*, combines data from the last two ATLAS runs, achieving a significance level of 3.4 standard deviations—an improvement over the 3.0 level previously reached by the CMS experiment.
This finding is crucial because it probes how the Higgs field gives mass to particles. In the Standard Model of particle physics, the Higgs boson’s interactions with particles, known as Yukawa couplings, determine their mass. item.title: Gender-Based Violence Rises in Argentina Amid Milei’s Rollback of Women’s Rights
item.description: The article explores the worsening crisis of gender-based violence in Argentina under President Javier Milei. It opens with the murder of Fernanda Soledad Yramain, a young mother from Tucumán who repeatedly sought police protection from her violent partner before being killed in 2024. Her case exemplifies what many activists see as a systemic collapse of safeguards for women. Since taking office in December 2023, Milei’s administration has dismantled institutions and programs aimed at preventing and addressing violence against women, such as the Ministry of Women and the Acompañar program. Funding cuts have led to reduced staff on emergency hotlines and fewer prosecutorial offices dedicated to gender violence cases. Data from the province of Tucumán show a sharp decline in protection orders and an increase in femicides. Nationally, 295 femicides were recorded in 2024, with a surge in early 2025. item.title: How AI and Robotics Are Transforming Scientific Research and Mexico’s Role in It
item.description:
The article explores how artificial intelligence and robotics are rapidly reshaping global scientific research, particularly through their integration into laboratory environments. In the United Kingdom, several university labs have begun using autonomous robots guided by AI to perform chemistry and materials science experiments around the clock. This continuous and precise automation is accelerating discovery cycles and yielding immense data sets, enabling deeper correlations and faster innovation in areas like materials, pharmaceuticals, and energy technologies.
According to recent reports, these systems function through integrated platforms combining robotic arms, sensors, predictive models, and optimization algorithms. In this collaborative model, robots carry out physical tasks, AI determines the next hypotheses, and human scientists focus on designing research lines and validating outcomes. item.title: Scientists map how the human brain learns and processes fear
item.description: Researchers from the Institut d’Investigacions Biomèdiques August Pi i Sunyer (IDIBAPS) in Barcelona have created the most detailed brain map to date showing how humans learn fear. Led by Enric Vilajosana, Miquel Àngel Fullana, and Joaquim Raduà, the study analyzed data from 42 previous experiments involving over 2,199 participants worldwide. They found that earlier inconsistencies in identifying brain areas involved in fear learning were due to limited statistical power rather than actual biological differences. By combining all available data, the team revealed that fear learning activates several interconnected brain regions, including the insula, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, premotor areas, anterior cingulate cortex, cerebellum, thalamus, caudate, and parts of the midbrain. Simultaneously, areas linked to the brain’s default mode network showed decreased activity, reflecting a shift of attention toward potential threats. item.title: Artificial Intelligence and the Telefónica Layoffs: The Contradictions of Capitalism in the Digital Era
item.description: The article examines how Telefónica’s restructuring, which includes one of the largest job cuts in its history—around 6,000 employees in Spain—reflects capitalism’s mounting contradictions under the rise of artificial intelligence (AI). Telefónica presents its workforce reduction as part of a strategic efficiency plan to cut debt and reallocate €3 billion by 2030 toward emerging sectors like AI and cybersecurity. However, the piece argues that this shift exposes deeper systemic issues: AI, while capable of producing abundance by automating work and optimizing resources, is deployed instead to preserve profitability and the capitalist order. Rather than being used to reduce working hours or redistribute productivity gains, technological advances are driving unemployment and social inequality. item.title: Putin Defends India’s Right to Buy Russian Energy Amid US Criticism
item.description:
During an exclusive interview with India Today ahead of his two-day visit to New Delhi, Russian President Vladimir Putin defended India’s right to maintain energy trade with Moscow despite pressure from the United States. He highlighted Washington’s continued purchase of uranium from Russia, which fuels American nuclear power plants, while at the same time urging New Delhi to reduce its imports of Russian oil. Putin pointed out the inconsistency in the US position, stating that if America has the right to buy fuel from Russia, India should enjoy the same privilege. Russia currently supplies about a quarter of the uranium used in US reactors, with estimated sales of $1.2 billion in 2025, up from $800 million in 2024.

item.title: Belgium's F-35 Purchase Faces Serious Operational Challenges
item.description: In 2018, Belgium purchased 34 F-35 fighter jets at a cost of €5.6 billion, a controversial decision that excluded the French Rafale and highlighted Europe's dependence on the United States for defense. The controversy grew with an opinion piece by Joren Vermeersch, an advisor to the Belgian Defense Minister, who insulted France and argued that rejecting American weapons would marginalize Europe strategically. Recently, the first F-35 arrived in Belgium, but it faced technical problems, and the country's limited airspace caused further complications. Belgium's airspace is among the most restricted in Europe, making it difficult to conduct the necessary training for such advanced jets. The Belgian government is now seeking agreements with NATO allies like Italy, Norway, and the Netherlands to access broader training areas. item.title: Samsung Prioritizes Data Center Clients as Memory Costs Surge
item.description:
The article reports on a growing crisis in the memory chip market, where skyrocketing RAM prices have forced major manufacturers like Samsung to prioritize sales to higher-paying clients. According to sources, Samsung Semiconductor recently declined an order from Samsung Electronics, its own consumer electronics division, for DRAM chips destined for next-generation Galaxy smartphones. The reason is the ongoing 'AI bubble,' which has caused unprecedented demand for high-performance memory used in artificial intelligence data centers. With data center companies willing to pay premium prices, chipmakers such as Samsung, SK Hynix, and Micron are channeling resources toward that market segment.

item.title: Actor Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, Famous for 'Mortal Kombat', Passes Away at 75
item.description: Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, the Japanese American actor celebrated for his iconic portrayal of Shang Tsung in 'Mortal Kombat,' has passed away at the age of 75 due to complications from a stroke. Born in Japan and partly raised on U.S. military bases, Tagawa moved to Los Angeles where he developed his own martial arts style, Chu Shin. Discovered by director Bernardo Bertolucci, he gained international recognition with a role in the 1987 Oscar-winning film 'The Last Emperor,' and went on to appear in over 30 films. Tagawa often portrayed elegant and cunning villains, becoming a staple of action cinema. Beyond his film work, he served as a mentor to younger actors and martial artists, known for his generosity and charisma. His role as Shang Tsung became a cult classic, remembered for the line 'Your soul is mine,' and he reprised the character in the 2013 series 'Mortal Kombat: Legacy' and voiced him in the video game 'Mortal Kombat 11.' item.title: Africa's Strategic Minerals and the Global Race for Control
item.description: Africa has become the central stage of a fierce geopolitical and economic race over strategic minerals essential to powering modern technologies such as electric vehicle batteries, wind turbines, solar panels, and electronics. The continent holds vast reserves of key minerals—lithium, cobalt, copper, nickel, manganese, and rare earth elements—placing it at the crossroads of global industrial and political ambitions. The Democratic Republic of the Congo alone accounts for over 76% of the world’s cobalt supply, while Zimbabwe, Mali, and South Africa also host abundant reserves of lithium and other critical resources. China currently dominates the extraction, refining, and processing sectors, controlling up to 70% of global lithium and cobalt production chains. Its Belt and Road investments amount to more than $29 billion, much of it directed to mining infrastructure. item.description: The video appears to discuss claims made by Hegseth regarding a boat strike, suggesting that his story relies on misleading information framed as a 'fog of war.' The content likely analyzes or fact-checks these claims.

item.title: Analysis Reveals Most European Drone Sightings Were False Alarms
item.description:
Over recent months, numerous reports of unidentified drones near airports, ports, and military sites across Europe have caused alarm and speculation, particularly regarding possible Russian involvement. However, an investigation by the Dutch newspaper Trouw and the magazine Dronewatch analyzed 61 incidents across 11 countries between September 9 and November 27 and concluded that the vast majority lacked any tangible evidence of drones or foreign interference. Of those 61 sightings, 14 turned out to be other objects such as police helicopters or cargo planes, 41 had no verifiable proof or clear origin, while only three confirmed Russian drones were located in countries bordering Ukraine—Poland, Romania, and Moldova. This evidence does not substantiate claims of coordinated Russian activity in Western Europe.

item.description: A woman driving through Key Largo was violently pulled from her car and detained by federal agents early Wednesday morning, according to a video recorded by Miami Herald reporter David Goodhue. item.title: Mexico and Huawei Partner to Strengthen National Digital Talent and Innovation
item.description:
Mexico has taken a decisive step in advancing its digital transformation strategy through a new public-private partnership with Huawei. Announced on November 29, the initiative focuses on education and training in key technological areas such as artificial intelligence, data science, advanced networking, and cybersecurity. The agreement is set to benefit thousands of students, teachers, and developers through scholarships, technical certifications, and hands-on experience in innovation labs during 2025–2026. This move aims to enhance national expertise and prepare professionals for the growing demands of the digital economy.
Huawei will contribute by offering educational infrastructure, certified trainers, and proprietary course materials from its technology ecosystem, thereby improving the quality of training available in public institutions. item.title: Israel-backed Gaza Militia Leader Yasser Abu Shabab Killed in Rafah
item.description: Yasser Abu Shabab, leader of the Popular Forces militia and a key collaborator with Israeli forces, was reportedly killed on Thursday in Rafah, southern Gaza, an area under full Israeli control. Local and Israeli media outlets reported the death, though details on the perpetrator remain unclear, with some accounts suggesting an internal clash or shooting involving local families. Abu Shabab, a 35-year-old with a criminal background including convictions for theft and drug trafficking, escaped Hamas prison during early Israeli strikes and rebuilt his operations in eastern Rafah with Israeli arms, air cover, and coordination. His group faced widespread condemnation from Palestinian factions for looting humanitarian aid convoys, extorting civilians, attacking Palestinians, and alleged ties to ISIS, while aiding Israel's efforts against Hamas. item.title: Muslim-majority nations back China at the UN and reject U.S. narrative on Xinjiang
item.description:
The article reports that the United States' efforts to rally support against China at the United Nations over human rights concerns in Xinjiang have largely failed. Out of all UN member states, only fifteen countries — including the U.S., the U.K., Japan, and Israel — signed a joint declaration condemning China’s alleged abuses in Xinjiang. China’s counter-declaration, titled 'Opposition to the Politicization of Human Rights,' gathered 85 signatories, representing roughly half of the global population.
The report emphasizes that most Muslim-majority nations, including Saudi Arabia, Iran, Egypt, Nigeria, and Pakistan, chose to support China's stance instead of the U.S.-led declaration, revealing a major shift in diplomatic alignment. item.title: Italy temporarily halts new military support to Ukraine amid peace talks and funding strains
item.description:
The Italian government, led by Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, has decided to suspend further military support to Ukraine in light of ongoing peace negotiations and limited financial resources. Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani justified the move by saying it would be premature to join NATO’s new military procurement program for Ukraine, known as the Prioritised Ukraine Requirements List (PURL). The initiative allows NATO countries to jointly fund the purchase of U.S. weapons for Ukrainian defense. Tajani explained that if peace talks succeed and hostilities end, there will be no need for additional arms, but rather for security guarantees and reconstruction measures.
Rome’s decision marks the first explicit acknowledgment by a European government that continued military assistance might be counterproductive while ceasefire negotiations are under way. item.title: Media Silence over Palestine Action Prisoners on Hunger Strike in the UK
item.description:
The article by Jonathan Cook, published on Rafael Poch de Feliu’s blog, denounces the total absence of media coverage in the United Kingdom of six Palestine Action activists currently on hunger strike. These activists, imprisoned for attacking British arms factories supplying weapons to Israel, have been retroactively labeled as 'terrorists' under the UK’s expansive anti-terrorism legislation after the government banned their organization. Their protest aims to draw attention to what they consider illegal imprisonment and complicity in genocide in Gaza.
Cook contrasts the current silence with the 1980s IRA hunger strikes, which received broad and sustained media attention. He argues that today’s corporate and state-aligned press avoids coverage that might embarrass the government or expose repression against political dissent. item.title: YouTube deletes Palestinian human rights videos following U.S. sanctions
item.description: The article reports that YouTube, under pressure from U.S. sanctions imposed by the Trump administration, has deleted the accounts of three Palestinian human rights organizations — Al Haq, Al Mezan Center for Human Rights, and the Palestinian Center for Human Rights (PCHR). These groups had published more than 700 videos documenting alleged Israeli war crimes in Gaza and the West Bank, including civilian killings, home demolitions, and testimonies from victims. The decision followed new U.S. sanctions targeting groups cooperating with the International Criminal Court (ICC), which has been investigating Israeli officials, including Benjamin Netanyahu and Yoav Gallant, for alleged war crimes. According to YouTube’s statement, the deletions were part of compliance with U.S. sanctions law, but human rights advocates condemned the move as censorship and complicity in silencing Palestinian voices. item.title: Chinese Zhuque 3 Rocket Launches Successfully While First Stage Landing Fails
item.description: On December 3, 2025, the Chinese private aerospace company LandSpace successfully launched the first Zhuque 3 rocket, marking the first Chinese orbital vehicle with a partially reusable first stage. The mission, named 'Land to Infinity,' lifted off at 04:00 UTC from Launch Complex 96B in the Dongfeng Commercial Aerospace Testing Area near Jiuquan, Inner Mongolia. The second stage successfully reached orbit with a simulated payload, achieving an initial orbit of 142 x 402 km at a 56.95° inclination. However, the first stage failed to land on its dedicated platform 390 km away, experiencing an explosion during the final landing burn. Despite the setback, the stage reached an apogee of 120 km and performed a 46-second braking burn, demonstrating significant progress for a private Chinese aerospace company. item.title: Belgium Faces Major Labor Strikes Amid Political and Economic Challenges
item.description: Belgium is experiencing a deepening social and political crisis, exacerbated by recent labor unrest. The government is under pressure from Europe regarding Russian-held funds, while internally it struggles to function as a coalition of five disparate parties. Workers and pensioners staged a three-day strike, marking the largest mobilization since the famous 1960-1961 'Strike of the Century.' The strikes reflect growing dissatisfaction with working conditions and the government's austerity policies, which prioritize budget cuts over social welfare. The article compares current events to the historic strike, highlighting the political nature of past labor movements that opposed both government austerity and broader structural inequalities. Despite strong street mobilizations, the government continues to pursue austerity and maintain control, with minimal engagement with unions. item.title: How a Colonial Rat Bounty in Hanoi Backfired and Spread Disease
item.description: In early 1900s Hanoi, French colonial officials introduced a rat bounty program to curb plague outbreaks, offering a coin for every rat tail brought in. Initially, it seemed successful, but the policy quickly backfired. Hunters often cut off tails and released the rats to breed more, while some even raised rats deliberately for profit. This perverse incentive caused the rat population to increase, exposing hunters to greater plague risk and undermining public health efforts. The broader context involved unequal urban planning: European quarters received modern sewers, while Vietnamese neighborhoods were left with open gutters, exacerbating rat infestations. Experts highlight this as an early example of Goodhart’s Law, showing how poorly designed incentives can lead to unintended consequences. item.title: Congress Releases 2020 Photos and Videos of Jeffrey Epstein’s Caribbean Island for Transparency
item.description: On December 3, 2025, House Democrats released previously unseen images and videos of Jeffrey Epstein’s private Caribbean island, providing insight into the environment where he allegedly trafficked young girls. The materials, captured in 2020, a year after Epstein died in jail, show various areas of the property, including bedrooms, an office or library, a dentist chair room, and a chalkboard with words like 'fin', 'intellectual', 'deception', and 'power'. The release follows ongoing investigations into Epstein's crimes, including a 2022 settlement in which the US Virgin Islands attorney general secured over $100 million from Epstein’s estate after alleging sexual abuse and trafficking at Little St James, one of his two islands. Congressional leaders emphasized that while the images do not reveal new evidence, their release is part of a broader effort to maintain public transparency and pressure on the Justice Department to release additional files by the December 19 deadline. item.title: CDMX and Hidalgo Partner to Share Digital Tools for Government Modernization
item.description: On November 27, 2025, the governments of Mexico City (CDMX) and the State of Hidalgo officially announced a partnership aimed at modernizing public administration through digital innovation. The agreement allows Hidalgo to adopt a range of advanced digital platforms and systems developed by the Digital Agency for Public Innovation (ADIP) in Mexico City. These include digital authentication, unique digital records, remote procedures, digital citizen services, open data systems, and automated chatbots. By implementing these tools, Hidalgo aims to streamline administrative processes, reduce bureaucracy, enhance transparency, and improve citizen access to public services. For Mexico City, the collaboration reinforces its status as a national leader in digital government services. Hidalgo benefits by avoiding the cost and time required to develop its own systems, enabling more efficient allocation of resources. item.description: A group of House Republicans and Democrats, including Rep. Anna Paulina Luna (R-Fla.) and Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.), have joined forces to advance legislation banning members of Congress from trading stocks. Using a discharge petition—a procedural tactic previously employed to release the Jeffrey Epstein files—the coalition seeks to bypass House Speaker Mike Johnson, who has limited floor votes on certain issues. Once a discharge petition gains enough signatures and seven legislative days pass, a vote is automatically scheduled. The push reflects growing public concern over lawmakers using insider knowledge for personal financial gain, an issue highlighted during previous administrations but delayed under former Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Rep. Tim Burchett (R-Tenn.) described the coalition as surprising given its ideological diversity.
